aws::graph::propositions: # Definition and Limitations of Internal Control Over Financial Reporting
Internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding financial reporting reliability.
Internal control over financial reporting is designed to ensure reliable preparation of financial statements for external purposes.
Financial statements for external purposes must be prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
Internal control over financial reporting includes policies and procedures for maintaining detailed records.
These records must accurately reflect company transactions.
These records must fairly reflect company transactions.
These records must accurately reflect dispositions of company assets.
These records must fairly reflect dispositions of company assets.
Internal control over financial reporting includes policies providing reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary.
This recording of transactions permits preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
Internal control over financial reporting ensures company receipts are made only with authorization from management and directors.
Internal control over financial reporting ensures company expenditures are made only with authorization from management and directors.
Internal control over financial reporting provides reasonable assurance regarding prevention of unauthorized acquisition of company assets.
Internal control over financial reporting provides reasonable assurance regarding timely detection of unauthorized acquisition of company assets.
Internal control over financial reporting provides reasonable assurance regarding prevention of unauthorized use of company assets.
Internal control over financial reporting provides reasonable assurance regarding timely detection of unauthorized use of company assets.
Internal control over financial reporting provides reasonable assurance regarding prevention of unauthorized disposition of company assets.
Internal control over financial reporting provides reasonable assurance regarding timely detection of unauthorized disposition of company assets.
Unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of company assets could have a material effect on the financial statements.

details: unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition HAS EFFECT material

text:
#### Definition and Limitations of Internal Control Over Financial Reporting

A companys internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. A companys internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the companys assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
